Introduction

Essential (primary) hypertension is a chronic condition characterized by consistently elevated blood pressure without a known secondary cause.  It affects a significant portion of the adult population and is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, including myocardial infarction, stroke, and heart failure.  The etiology of essential hypertension is multifactorial and complex.

Pathophysiology

Key mechanisms likely include the following:

  • Genetic predisposition:  Several genetic loci have been associated with blood pressure regulation, influencing renal sodium handling, vascular tone, and sympathetic nervous system activity.
  • Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS):  Dysregulation of the RAAS leads to increased sodium and water retention, vasoconstriction, and aldosterone-mediated potassium excretion, all of which contribute to elevated blood pressure (
    figure 1
    ).  Many antihypertensive agents act on this system (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Endothelial dysfunction:  Impaired nitric oxide production and increased endothelin-1 levels lead to increased vascular tone.

Risk factors

Several risk factors are associated with the development of essential hypertension:

  • Age:  Blood pressure tends to increase with age.
  • Family history:  A family history of hypertension increases this risk.
  • Obesity:  Excess body weight is strongly linked to hypertension.
  • Dietary factors:  High sodium intake, low potassium intake, and excessive alcohol consumption all can raise blood pressure.
  • Physical inactivity:  A sedentary lifestyle contributes to the development of hypertension.
  • Ethnicity:  There is a higher prevalence in certain ethnic groups, such as African Americans.

Clinical presentation

Essential hypertension typically presents as slowly rising blood pressures over months to years; an abrupt elevation is atypical and suggests a secondary cause.  It is usually asymptomatic and discovered during healthcare encounters for other reasons.

Symptoms may be reported but are nonspecific and often better attributed to other conditions; when truly due to hypertension, the presence of symptoms may indicate severe blood pressure elevations and end-organ damage.  Commonly reported symptoms include the following:

  • Headache
  • Fatigue
  • Chest pain
  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Dizziness and/or palpitations
  • Visual disturbances

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of essential hypertension is based on serial measurement of blood pressure using a sphygmomanometer, using correct technique including appropriate cuff size (

figure 3
).

Classification

Blood pressure classification varies; one classification is as follows:

  • Normal:  systolic <120 mm Hg, diastolic <80 mm Hg
  • Elevated:  systolic 120-129 mm Hg, diastolic <80 mm Hg
  • Stage 1 hypertension:  systolic 130-139 mm Hg and/or diastolic 80-89 mm Hg
  • Stage 2 hypertension:  systolic â‰¥140 mm Hg and/or diastolic â‰¥90 mm Hg

Measurement

The diagnosis is most often based on office-based blood pressure measurement.  However, other testing modalities can be useful, particularly if office readings are inconsistent or if white-coat hypertension (ie, blood pressure is elevated only in health care settings) or masked hypertension (ie, blood pressure is generally elevated but office-based readings are normal) is suspected.

Options include the following:

  • Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring:  Automated devices intermittently measure blood pressure, typically over 24 hours, and record pressure at different times of the day and while sleeping.  Daytime blood pressure â‰¥130/80 mm Hg, nocturnal blood pressure â‰¥110/65 mm Hg, or overall 24-hour average blood pressure â‰¥125/75 mm Hg confirms the diagnosis of hypertension.
  • Home blood pressure monitoring:  Inexpensive devices can be used for self-measurement of blood pressure.  This option is useful for initial diagnosis as well as for following response to treatment.

Laboratory/imaging evaluation

Diagnostic testing in essential hypertension is directed to identify potential correctable causes of elevated blood pressure, detect additional cardiovascular risk factors that could impact management, and screen for hypertensive complications.  Initial evaluation includes the following:

  • Basic metabolic panel to assess renal function and electrolyte levels
  • Lipid profile to evaluate cholesterol and triglyceride levels
  • Fasting blood glucose or hemoglobin A1c to screen for diabetes mellitus
  • Urinalysis to detect proteinuria or hematuria
  • ECG to assess for left ventricular hypertrophy or other cardiac abnormalities
  • Echocardiography if there are signs of heart failure or left ventricular hypertrophy, which is classically concentric (
    figure 4
    ) and associated with impaired diastolic filling

Additional studies are indicated in patients in whom secondary hypertension is suspected.

Differential diagnosis

Besides essential hypertension, other major conditions associated with elevated blood pressure include the following:

Secondary hypertension

Elevated blood pressure can be due to an identifiable comorbid disorder.  Common secondary causes (described in detail in a separate article) include the following:

  • Renal and renovascular disease:  Features that suggest renal parenchymal disease include proteinuria, hematuria, and abnormal renal function tests.  Features that suggest renovascular hypertension include renal bruit, widespread atherosclerotic disease, severe or resistant hypertension (ie, uncontrolled despite an appropriate 3-drug regimen), and recurrent flash pulmonary edema.
  • Endocrine disorders:
    • Hyperaldosteronism:  This disorder is to be considered in patients with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and mild hypernatremia; severe hypokalemia may be precipitated by diuretics.
    • Pheochromocytoma:  In patients with paroxysmal hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis, pheochromocytoma should be considered.
    • Cushing syndrome:  This disorder can be considered in patients with abrupt weight gain, moon face, "buffalo hump," and abdominal skin striae (
      figure 5
      ).
    • Thyroid disease:  Hyperthyroidism causes primarily systolic hypertension and tachycardia, whereas hypothyroidism commonly causes mild diastolic hypertension.
  • Obstructive sleep apnea:  Consider this disorder in patients with excessive daytime sleepiness, snoring, and witnessed apneas (very common cause of resistant hypertension).
  • Medications:  Commonly used medications that can elevate blood pressure include oral contraceptive pills, corticosteroids, and oral decongestants.

White-coat hypertension

Elevated blood pressure readings in a clinical setting (but normal readings outside of this setting) can occur.

Masked hypertension

Normal blood pressure readings in a clinical setting (but elevated readings outside of this setting) can occur.

Isolated systolic hypertension

This condition is generally defined as systolic blood pressure â‰¥140 mm Hg with diastolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg (varies with guidelines).  It is most common in elderly patients due to age-related increased rigidity (decreased compliance) of the walls of the aorta and other large arteries.  Management with lifestyle modifications and pharmacologic therapy is warranted.

Management

The management of essential hypertension involves lifestyle modifications and pharmacologic therapy.

Lifestyle modifications

Lifestyle interventions for hypertension are summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  They include the following:

Dietary changes

  • Reduce sodium intake (<2.3 g sodium/day).
  • Increase potassium intake through fruits and vegetables.
  • Follow the DASH diet (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension).

Weight loss

  • Achieve and maintain a healthy body weight (BMI 18-25 kg/m2).

Physical activity

  • Engage in regular aerobic exercise (eg, 30 min of moderate-intensity exercise most days of the week).

Limit alcohol intake

  • Limit intake to â‰¤2 drinks per day for men and â‰¤1 one drink per day for women.

Smoking cessation

  • Strongly advise complete cessation to all patients.

Pharmacological therapy

The choice of drug is determined largely by patient factors, including comorbidities, concurrent medications, and adverse effects profile (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  First-line antihypertensive medications include the following:

Thiazide diuretics

  • Commonly used agents:  hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone, indapamide
  • Mechanism:  increase sodium and water excretion by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule (
    figure 6
    ); they also have a mild vasodilating effect.
  • Compelling indications:  may be beneficial in patients with osteoporosis due to reduction in renal calcium excretion.  Avoid in patients with orthostatic hypotension or gout.
  • Adverse effects:  hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, hyperglycemia (especially in patients with diabetes mellitus), hyperuricemia

ACE inhibitors (ACEIs)

  • Commonly used agents:  lisinopril, ramipril, captopril, quinapril, enalapril, trandolapril, moexipril
  • Mechanism:  inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, reducing vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion
  • Compelling indications:  heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, diabetic nephropathy with albuminuria
  • Adverse effects:  cough (due to elevated bradykinin levels) (
    figure 7
    ), hyperkalemia, angioedema, renal impairment (30% rise in creatinine is expected and should not prompt discontinuation)

Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)

  • Commonly used agents:  losartan, candesartan, irbesartan, olmesartan, valsartan, azilsartan
  • Mechanism:  block angiotensin II receptors, reducing vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion
  • Compelling indications:  similar to ACEIs; also consider in patients with cough on ACEI therapy.
  • Adverse effects:  hyperkalemia, renal impairment, rare angioedema

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs)

  • Commonly used agents:
    • Dihydropyridines:  nifedipine, amlodipine, felodipine
    • Nondihydropyridines:  verapamil, diltiazem
  • Mechanism:  inhibit calcium entry into vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasodilation
  • Compelling indications:  angina, arrhythmias (eg, nondihydropyridines in patients with atrial fibrillation)
  • Adverse effects:  peripheral edema, constipation, bradycardia

Beta blockers

  • Commonly used agents:  atenolol, metoprolol, propranolol, labetalol, bisoprolol, carvedilol, nebivolol, nadolol
  • Mechanism:  block beta-adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and cardiac output
  • Compelling indications:  coronary heart disease with recent myocardial infarction, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, arrhythmias (eg, atrial fibrillation); not preferred first-line agents for uncomplicated hypertension.
  • Adverse effects:  bradycardia, fatigue, depression, bronchospasm (in asthma), decreased insulin sensitivity

Combination therapy

Combination therapy may be required for patients with moderate to severe hypertension or who do not achieve target blood pressure with monotherapy.  Care is necessary to avoid additive adverse effects (eg, an ACEI with an ARB or aldosterone antagonist can cause severe hyperkalemia).

  • Combination of a CCB (eg, amlodipine) with an ACEI or ARB may be favorable for many patients.
  • Low-dose thiazide diuretics also are favorable in combination with other drugs (combination tablets are widely available).

Other agents

In addition to these agents, others may be appropriate for primary therapy in patients with certain comorbid conditions or for add-on therapy in patients who do not achieve adequate blood pressure lowering despite appropriate first-line options.  Potential drugs include the following:

  • Loop diuretics (eg, furosemide, torsemide) are useful in heart failure with volume overload (or for other patients with refractory edema).
  • Alpha blockers (eg, doxazosin, terazosin, prazosin) are useful in benign prostatic hyperplasia with urinary obstruction.
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (eg, spironolactone, eplerenone) are useful in patients with heart failure or refractory hypertension.
  • Centrally acting agents (eg, clonidine, guanfacine) are occasionally useful for refractory hypertension, especially in patients on dialysis; clonidine is sometimes used short term in the management of severe hypertension/hypertensive urgency.
  • Vasodilators (eg, hydralazine) are occasionally used in resistant hypertension and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (with isosorbide dinitrate).
  • Sodium glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors (eg, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) are primarily used for treating type 2 diabetes mellitus but have a notable blood pressure lowering effect; they are sometimes used as adjunctive therapy in patients without diabetes mellitus but with cardiovascular or renal comorbidity.  SGLT-2 inhibitors are also useful in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

In pregnancy, some medications are contraindicated (teratogenic) or poorly studied; therefore, in patients with hypertension who are pregnant or considering pregnancy, medications should be changed to ones safe for use (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).

Prognosis and complications

Essential hypertension is typically slowly progressive over time, often requiring periodic adjustments to therapy.  Uncontrolled hypertension can lead to serious complications, including:

  • Hypertensive emergencies:  acute, severe elevations in blood pressure with end-organ damage (eg, hypertensive encephalopathy, acute coronary syndrome)
  • Cardiovascular disease:  increased risk for myocardial infarction, heart failure, and stroke
  • Chronic kidney disease:  progressive renal impairment and potential for end-stage renal disease
  • Retinopathy:  hypertensive damage to retinal blood vessels, leading to vision loss
  • Peripheral artery disease:  reduced blood flow to the limbs, causing pain and tissue damage
  • Aortic aneurysm and dissection:  weakened and dilated aortic walls prone to rupture

Several of these conditions are discussed in separate articles.

Nonadherence with antihypertensive medication is a common reason for poor blood pressure control in hypertensive patients.  Motivation is particularly difficult in chronic, silent illnesses, in which many patients are initially asymptomatic and have no immediate, perceived benefit to adherence.  Causes of nonadherence should be evaluated systematically (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).

Screening

Routine blood pressure screening is essential for early detection and management.  Recommendations include the following:

  • Adults age 18-39:  blood pressure measurement at least every 3-5 years
  • Adults age â‰¥40 or at increased risk:  annual blood pressure measurement

More frequent screening may be appropriate for patients with elevated (nonhypertensive) blood pressure or comorbid conditions (eg, obesity) that raise the risk for hypertension.

Special consideration:  pediatric hypertension

Hypertension in children is often defined as blood pressure â‰¥95th percentile for the patient's height, sex, and age.  Personal and family history (eg, essential hypertension, stroke), examination, and basic laboratory studies are aimed at distinguishing between primary (essential) and secondary hypertension; a possible approach is presented in this figure (

figure 8
).  Secondary hypertension is common, particularly among prepubertal children; renal causes are most likely, including glomerulonephritis and parenchymal scarring (eg, from vesicoureteral reflux or congenital anomalies).  However, primary (essential) hypertension is increasing in prevalence, in parallel with childhood obesity; it is more common in older children and adolescents.  Screening for hypertension often begins at age 3 (or younger in patients with risk factors).

Summary

Essential hypertension is a common and multifactorial condition characterized by elevated blood pressure without a secondary cause.  Understanding its pathophysiology, risk factors, and clinical presentation is crucial for accurate diagnosis and effective management.  Early intervention through lifestyle modifications and appropriate pharmacologic therapy can prevent complications and improve prognosis.  Regular screening and monitoring are vital for maintaining blood pressure control and reducing the burden of hypertension-related morbidity and mortality.
